Roof slope is the vertical rise in
inches for every horizontal distance
of twelve inches (called the "run"). It
is expressed as rise:run or, in this
example 6:12.
Note: On a drawing this slope
might also be represented as:
12
6

visual_elements.description: A table titled 'Structure' with two columns: 'Structure' and 'Max. height to roof peak'. It lists different types of dwellings and their corresponding maximum height limits.

A diagram illustrating how to determine the slope of a roof, labeled 'Fig 43 Determining slope of roof'. It shows a cross-section of a roof with a horizontal 'run' of 12 inches and a vertical 'rise' of 6 inches, indicating the slope.

A diagram labeled 'Fig 42 Comparison of roof slopes' showing five house silhouettes with different roof slopes (12:14, 12:12, 12:10, 12:6, 12:3) and their corresponding height limits (33' or 30'). The height is measured to the top of the roof material.

qualifiers.text: on a substandard or flag lot

execution_sequence.action: Determine the structure type and lot type.
If 'Main dwelling' and 'on a standard lot' and 'with a roof slope <12:12', then Max. height to roof peak is 30'.
If 'Main dwelling' and 'on a standard lot' and 'with a roof slope ≥12:12', then Max. height to roof peak is 33'.
If 'Main dwelling' and 'on a substandard or flag lot', then Max. height to roof peak is 17'.
If 'Accessory structure' and 'in rear or side yard', then Max. height to roof peak is 12'.
If '2nd-dwelling units', then Max. height to roof peak is 17'.
